STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 12, 2021
Delora O’Neill
Wellspring Lutheran Services Gaylord
1260 South Otsego Ave
Gaylord, MI 49735
RE: License #: CB690358779
Wellspring Lutheran Services Gaylord
1260 South Otsego Ave
Gaylord, MI 49735
Dear Ms. O’Neill:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 7, 2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP failed to achieve compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, Area Manager, at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 383-5531
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services

Gaylord, MI 49735

SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least annually
and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
Six foster home files were reviewed. One of 6 files did not contain an updated
parent/agency agreement. The last signed agreement was dated September 2,
2019.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. One of 9 files did not contain a
physical exam which was due December 17, 2020.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. One of 9 files contained an ISP that
was late. The plan was due on March 11, 2020 and was completed on March 12,
2020.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. One of 9 files contained a USP that
was late. The plan was due on March 16, 2020 and was completed on March 17,
2020.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. Two of 9 files did not contain an
updated independent living contract. This is a repeat violation. The original
violation was established during the Interim Inspection completed on January 30,
2020, and an acceptable CAP was received on March 23, 2020.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and service plans.
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s
supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to
participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not available
or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include an
explanation of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify
any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their participation in
services.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. One of 9 files did not document the
parent’s signature on a PATP dated November 23, 2020.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
5

Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. Two of 9 files did not contain FTM’s
that were completed within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date. One file
did not contain an FTM for the service plan period. One file documented that the
FTM occurred on December 17, 2020 for a service plan due December 1, 2020. The
FTM was late. This is a third repeat violation. The original violation was
established during the Interim Inspection completed on 02/14/18 and an acceptable
CAP was received on 03/28/18. A repeat violation was established during the
renewal inspection completed on January 10, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was
received on January 17, 2019. A second repeat violation was established during the
Interim Inspection completed on January 30, 2020 and an acceptable corrective
action plan was received on March 23, 2020.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts – Timely Entry
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. Four of 9 files contained one or more
face to face contacts that were entered after 5 business days. This is a second
repeat violation. The original violation was established during the renewal
inspection completed on January 10, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was received on
January 17, 2019. A repeat violation was established during the Interim Inspection
completed on January 30, 2020 and an acceptable corrective action plan was
received on March 23, 2020.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the child's placement setting each subsequent calendar month.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. One of 9 files contained a contact
dated December 22, 2020 that did not contain a narrative. The agency submitted a
hard copy indicating that the contact occurred and it contained a narrative however
the contact’s narrative was not uploaded. This is a repeat violation. The original
violation was established during the Interim Inspection completed on January 30,
2020 and an acceptable CAP was received on March 23, 2020.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
6

Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. Two of 9 files did not contain current
medical passports. One file contained medical passports completed on February 3,
2020 and December 18, 2020. There was a 9 month gap when passports were not
updated. A second file documented that the last updated passport occurred on
August 19, 2020. This is a repeat violation. The original violation was established
during the Interim Inspection completed on January 30, 2020 and an acceptable
CAP was received on March 23, 2020.
FOM 722-08C Parent/Agency Treatment Plans
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
Nine files and 28 service plans were reviewed. Three of 9 files contained PATP’s
that were not signed. One file contained a PATP dated September 17, 2020 that was
not signed by the foster parent. A second file contained a PATP dated September
11, 2020 that was signed late by the foster parent on November 12, 2020. A third file
contained two PATP’s dated August 17, 2020, and May 9, 2020, that lacked foster
parent signatures. This is a fifth repeat violation. The original violation was
established during the Interim inspection completed on February 23, 2016 and an
acceptable CAP was received on April 7, 2016. A repeat violation was established
was established during the Renewal Inspection completed on December 12, 2016
and an acceptable CAP was received on January 20, 2017. A second repeat
violation was established during the Interim Inspection completed February 2, 2018
and an acceptable corrective action plan was received on March 3, 2018. A third
repeat violation was established during the renewal inspection completed on
January 10, 2019 and an acceptable CAP was received on January 17, 2020. A
fourth repeat violation was established during the Interim Inspection completed on
January 30, 2020 and an acceptable CAP was received on March 23, 2020.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
None required.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not required or requested at this time.
7

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care, child abuse and/or
neglect during or corporal punishment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Interim Inspection: On March 23, 2020, an acceptable corrective action plan was
received in response to those violations established during the Interim Inspection
completed on January 30, 2020.
Special Investigations:
SI #2020C0634022. CAP approved September 2, 2020.
SI #2020C0114030. CAP approved September 3, 2020.
SI #2020C0114013. CAP approved March 2, 2020.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
January 8, 2021
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 12, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
8
